 Well, your teacher is wrong.
 
 First, let's take the "laws are based off (on) the commandments." There are actually at least two versions of the "10 Commandments," probably more. Except for "thou shalt not kill" and "thou shalt not steal", what laws are there that echo the ten commandments? Possibly you could present a case that "thou shalt not bear false witness" is the basis of perjury laws. But what law declares that "I am the Lord thy God?" What law makes it illegal to covet my neighbor's wife? Where is it a criminal offense to commit adultry? There are only two, at best three commandments that are incorporated into law. And if these commandments are really the basis of our laws, then wouldn't it be reasonable the assume that cultures that had never heard of the ten commandments wouldn't have such laws? But if you look into the matter you will find that laws against murder, theft, and even lying to legal authorities are almost universal. These are recognized conventions of an orderly society.
 
 The matter of "nobody is forcing people to read or look at the public display" is a bit more subtle. In effect, the answer is, "So what? It is still a violation of the Constitution." The posting of religious monuments by the government are almost always violations of the 1st Amendment (as incorporated against the states by the 14th Amendment). Here's why. The Supreme Court (whose sole job is to decide the meaning of the Constitution) has found on several occasions that the purpose of the establishment clause of the 1st Amendment is to prevent government from endorsing or supporting religion. Unless one can support the ridiculous assertion that the ten commandments are not religious, then their posting in government buildings of any kind are a violation of the Constitution.
 
 An additional point. Those who agree with the posting of religious icons are required to make no acknowledgement of that agreement. Thus, the actions of those who disagree are indistinguishable from those who agree. The Supreme Court has found that such cases are violations of the 1st Amendment. This was the basis of decisions against the "stand and be silent while the teacher recites a (christian) prayer" laws. Participation and non-participation were the same. Even laws that excused objectors have been found unconstitutional because they single out dissenters for persecution.
